entry.title: SAP HANA Database Encryption (PERSISTENCE, LOG, BACKUP volumes) related questions.
entry.content:
Hi SAP,

Good Day!

We have successfully configured and enabled HANA database encryption for the PERSISTENCE, LOG, and BACKUP volumes on both SYSTEMDB and TENANT DB in one of our sandbox systems as a part of PoC. This system has HANA  System Replication (HSR) enabled and the configuration was performed by following the referenced SAP Help documentation. 

Please review the attached task list excel, which contains the detailed execution steps and confirm whether we can proceed with implementing the same configuration across the remaining environments up to production.

We would appreciate your clarification and confirmation on the following points:

  1. Is it required to copy the Instance SSFS master keys and PKI SSFS keys from the primary HANA database to the secondary HANA database? If so, at what stage should this activity be performed?

  2. Should daily backups also be configured for the secondary HANA database? Please advise on SAP recommendation/best practice.

  3. Are there any additional considerations or steps that need to be taken into account for HANA database encryption during HSR failover, takeover, and failback operations?

  4. How can we validate and ensure that the PERSISTENCE, LOG, and BACKUP volumes are encrypted at the secondary HANA database site?

Thank you!


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA Database Encryption (PERSISTENCE, LOG, BACKU...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Please refer to the answers below.

1. Is it required to copy the Instance SSFS master keys and PKI SSFS keys from the primary HANA database to the secondary HANA database? If so, at what stage should this activity be performed?
=> A: Yes, the system PKI SSFS .key and the .dat file should be copied from the primary system to the secondary system before configuring the system replication.
This is one of the General Prerequisites before configuring the system replication.
Please refer to the 'Authorization' section in System Replication guide below.

2. Should daily backups also be configured for the secondary HANA database? Please advise on SAP recommendation/best practice.
=> A: HANA database backups can be done only from the primary site.
Please refer to the question '10. Is it possible to take backups on the secondary site?' in KBA 1999880 - FAQ:SAP HANA System Replication. 
"No, currently you can only take data and log backups on the primary site.
If automatic log backup is enabled, after takeover to the secondary site the log backups will automatically be written there."

3. Are there any additional considerations or steps that need to be taken into account for HANA database encryption during HSR failover, takeover, and failback operations?
=> A: If you have copied the system PKI SSFS key and dat file from the primary to secondary site correctly and configured the system replication, there are no additional manual steps are required for SAP HANA database encryption during HSR failover, takeover, or failback operations.
You can double confirm it by executing the SQL statement 'SELECT * FROM M_ENCRYPTION_OVERVIEW;' in the NEW primary system.

4. How can we validate and ensure that the PERSISTENCE, LOG, and BACKUP volumes are encrypted at the secondary HANA database site?
=> A: In case it's ACTIVE/ACTIVE system replication(logreplay_readaccess operation mode), you can run a query below to check this out after logging in to the secondary site.
SELECT * FROM M_ENCRYPTION_OVERVIEW;

If the secondary site is not read-enabled, the SQL access to system views is not possible.
In SAP HANA system replication, persistence, data and log volume encryption is configured on the primary system and automatically replicated to the secondary system.
Since system replication status is ACTIVE, the secondary system uses the same encryption configuration as the primary system.

You can also see the statement below in 'Enable Encryption' in HANA admin guide. 
"In a system-replication configuration, enable (or disable) encryption in the primary system only. The setting will be propagated to all secondary systems. The secondary systems must be running and replicating."

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Purchasing of Fixed Assets
entry.content:
The cost center in the fixed asset master data is considered the controlling object for depreciation and postings, so the system automatically defaults to that cost center when you procure against the asset. Changing the cost center at the purchase order level is not standard behavior—the system enforces consistency between the asset master and transactional postings.

That said, there are workarounds depending on your business requirement:

Workarounds & Options

1. Use Internal Orders or WBS Elements
Instead of trying to override the cost center, assign an internal order or WBS element in the PO. These can carry the budget responsibility (like CC2000) while the asset master retains CC1000 for depreciation. Costs flow to the order/WBS, and settlement rules can later move values to the asset.

2. Asset Under Construction (AuC) Approach
Create an AuC asset linked to CC2000 for procurement. Once capitalization occurs, transfer the asset to the final FA master with CC1000. This way, procurement hits CC2000, but depreciation later uses CC1000.

3. Custom Account Assignment Category
You already created a custom account assignment. However, SAP Cloud restricts overriding the cost center field when the asset number is entered. A workaround is to design the account assignment so that budget objects (cost center, order, WBS) are captured separately from the asset field, but this requires careful configuration and may still be limited.

4. Mass Update of Asset Master Data
If business requires frequent changes, you can use APIs for Asset Accounting or the Manage Fixed Assets app to update cost centers in master data. But this changes the depreciation cost center itself, not just the PO.

Having said that, the cleanest approach is:

  • Keep asset master cost center for depreciation (CC1000).
  • Use internal orders/WBS elements for procurement budget control (CC2000).
  • Settle costs from the order/WBS to the asset.

This aligns with SAP’s best practice in Public Cloud and avoids conflicts with system restrictions.

entry.title: The updated Planned Effort is not replicated to RM
entry.content:
After initial replication, the updated Planned Effort will not be replicated to Resource Request in RM.
That's the current designed behavior.
The resource manager might adjust the value in "Manage Reource Requests" app within RM.

Here are the relevant help documents:

  1. Help document for Professional Services Projects:
    https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/1986ee33c3934697a52cad407609ea36.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST
    >>>
    If the delta load contains changes to the required effort, or billing control category, resource management displays these changes in the demand details. However, they are not copied into the resource request details. This is to avoid that the system overwrites adjustments that the requester made in the request details.

    https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/9d477fe4824d4ddf89a1e40766dc48c3.html#results-1
    >>>
    With the initial load, the required effort and the requested service organization are copied into the resource request details, where they can be adjusted by the requester. 

  2. Help document for Enterprise Projects:
    https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/65de05f4fdda4eab8172d60a2cb30476.html#results-1
    >>>
    With the initial replication, the required effort is copied into the resource request details, where it can be adjusted by the requester. 

To address this, I ran tests in my internal system and compiled the behaviors with sample scenarios. I hope this provides a clearer understanding.

For Enterprise Projects:

1. In initial replication, the Planned Effort is 120h in project demand in S4HC.

2. It's replicated to "Manage Resource Requests" app in RM successfully.
If you click into the request, the 'Estimated Effort' under "Project Information" tab and 'Required Effort' under "Effort" tab are both 120h.

3. Then go back to S4HC project demand, update the Planned Effort to 90h.

4. The updated effort is replicated to  'Estimated Effort' under "Project Information" tab. But in 'Required Effort' under "Effort" tab it's still 120h.

entry.content:
Hi SAP team,
In a dataflow, I need the record.evaluate component to go to the error branch.
I used return null; but it still goes to the success branch.
How can I send it to the error branch without causing the dataflow to fail?
Kind regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: the record.evaluate component to go to the error branch
entry.content:
Hi Team,

 

You need to use the error handler customer script.

You can refer the following documentation IdentitySync Custom Scripts.

 

error: sends a failed record to the error path (for example, for writing to a separate file). Example:

function process(record, ctx, logger, next, error) {error.accept(record, record);
}

 

Best Regards,

SAP

entry.title: Guidance on Implementing "Contains" Filter Option in Solution Documentation Scope
entry.content:
I would like to implement an enhancement to Solution Documentation in Solution Manager 7.2: add a "Contains" option to the filter operator options when creating a Scope. I plan to develop this enhancement myself, but I need guidance on feasibility and starting points.
A few background points:

  • I will perform the enhancement personally. I have ABAP development experience but no SAP Web Dynpro experience.
  • I located two prior SAP tickets from our team requesting this feature; both were closed by SAP citing complexity and the EOL plan for SolMan 7.2 in DIGITS. Link to ticket 1 and ticket 2
  • Given the previous SAP responses, I want to confirm whether it is technically feasible for us to extend the UI/behavior ourselves and what the recommended development path would be.
  • This feature will be really helpful for our users to create the scope based on wildcard filter.

Could you please advise on the following:

  1. Feasibility
    • Is adding a "Contains" operator to the filter options in Solution Documentation technically feasible via customer/local enhancements without modifying core delivered objects?
    • Are there standard extension points, customer exits, BAdIs, or enhancement frameworks recommended for modifying Solution Documentation UI behavior in SolMan 7.2?
  2. Suggested starting points and resources
    • Which components, BSP/Web Dynpro applications, or SAP UI components should I examine first?
    • Are there specific classes, views, or controller files commonly involved in Scope filter rendering that I should inspect?
    • Any recommended SAP notes, development guides, or examples for adding filter operators or extending Solution Manager Web Dynpro UIs?
  3. Development approach and best practices
    • Is it better to implement changes via enhancement framework / Web Dynpro component extensions or via overlay/custom UI (e.g., custom Web Dynpro application that complements standard functionality)?
    • Any version-specific caveats for SolMan 7.2 (patch level considerations) we should be aware of?
  4. Support and maintenance implications
    • If we implement this enhancement ourselves (e.g., by modifying or extending UI components), will SAP support be impacted? Will such changes affect eligibility for OSS support or future patches/notes?
    • Are there recommended ways to implement the change to minimize issues with future SAP support, patches, or updates (for example, encapsulated custom components or transport-isolated modifications)?
  5. Security, performance, and test considerations
    • Any known performance or security considerations when adding additional filter operators in Solution Documentation scopes?
    • Recommended test coverage or scenarios to validate the enhancement safely before deploying to Quality/Production.

I appreciate any guidance, references to relevant notes or documents, and suggestions on a safe development strategy. If you prefer, I can also provide more specifics about the UI screens, current component names, or screenshots once I identify them.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

Solman 7.2 will reach end of mainstream maintenance in 2027. In line with this decision, the development team is focusing on maintaining the stability and reliability of the current version rather than introducing new features.
So no new functionalities or enhancements will be delivered.

entry.title: Delays, Drama, and Dancing Project Deadlines ? How to turn project procurement into a clockwork
entry.content:
In project-driven manufacturing businesses, successfully delivering on time versus experiencing cost and timeline overruns often hinges on one crucial factor: how well the project schedule aligns with procurement and production of necessary materials and components.

When project milestones and material deliveries move in lockstep, you reduce manual coordination, prevent site disruptions due to missing parts, and keep financials aligned with reality. When they don’t, delays multiply, buffers evaporate, and teams spend valuable time firefighting.

This post explains why integrating project schedules with the purchasing process managed in SAP Cloud ERP is critical, using a real-world manufacturing example, and outlines the benefits of an automated approach.

Let's consider a real-world scenario involving an engineer-to-order project within the industrial manufacturing sector.

Image: Simplified overview of stages in Engineer-to-Order Projects

A component manufacturer designs, produces, and installs gas turbines tailored to specific customer requirements. Each customer sales order functions as a project with distinct phases for engineering, fabrication, assembly, and commissioning. Manufacturing the turbine involves procuring and producing long-lead materials such as servo motors and compressors.

Below image illustrates a sample project plan as managed in SAP Project and Resource Management, a new tool on the SAP Business Technology Platform. It integrates closely with the financial and logistics processes in SAP Cloud ERP

The project is set to start on October 8th and continue until August 2025, when the turbine is delivered to the customer. It's organized into phases like Engineering, Procurement Planning, Production, Delivery, and Billing/Closure. Each phase is further detailed with tasks and subtasks. The application offers project scheduling capabilities that optimize the schedule based on task relationships, date constraints, and estimated task durations.

According to the project plan, manufacturing activities are scheduled to commence on December 17th, when required components are delivered and available to the production line.

Image: Manage Project Schedule in SAP Project and Resource Management 

The Unexpected happened and the chaos starts - project get's delayed 

During a design review with the customer, the engineering team identifies a design change affecting motor specifications. Consequently, the design work is extended by 40 days, with the design task now set to finish by December 10th. Considering this delay, we can use SAP Project and Resource Management's scheduling feature to reschedule the project. Due to task dependencies, manufacturing work is postponed by four weeks, with a new start date of January 26th (see image below).

Image: Rescheduling the project timeline in SAP Project and Resource Management due to delayed design work in the engineering phase.

Let's review what happens after timelines have been shifted in the case project planning is disconnected from the procurement planning. 

As soon as the baseline version of the project schedule has been finalized, the procurement team will typically use this version to plan the procurement of components as specified by the project engineers. With ongoing changes to the project plan—for example, shifting timelines due to unexpected design work—there is a high likelihood that requested delivery dates will not be updated in the procurement plan unless someone manually informs the procurement team of the amended plan. This misalignment can lead to several issues:

  • Required materials will arrive early, occupy warehouse and staging space, and tie up working capital.
    • Items tied to unfinalized design must be reworked or reordered, causing additional cost and complexity.
    • Finance recognizes Goods Receipt (GR) and planned Work in Progress (WIP) is out of sync with actual progress; forecasted cash outflows shift unexpectedly.
    • Project managers manually email buyers to adjust delivery dates; buyers then renegotiate with suppliers and update purchase orders—often missing some items or updating late.
    • Signals for downstream Material Requirements Planning (MRP)  become unreliable.

How to turn project procurement from chaos into a clockwork discipline - The integrated way !

Now, let's examine what happens in an integrated project management environment where project scheduling information automatically synchronizes with downstream procurement and production processes, as provided today in SAP Cloud ERP with SAP Project and Resource Management.

Based on the baseline project schedule, the project planner have already created in the "Manage Project Demand App"  in SAP Cloud ERP  a project demand for material MZ-RD-ET03 (Compressor) needed for the manufacturing tasks. Three units of this compressor are requested for delivery by December 17th. Importantly, the delivery date is automatically derived from the linked Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) associated with the manufacturing task.

Image: Project Demand App in SAP cloud ERP specifies material requirements including delivery date in synch with  project element start date

Earlier, we discussed an event which caused the delay in design work pushing manufacturing tasks to January 26th.

Image: In SAP Project and Resource Management “Start Date” of manufacturing task has been shifted to Jan 26.

Let's review now the updated project demand for the three compressors:

Image: Project demand app with updated demand date information derived automatically from project element start date

Notice that the demand date for the compressors has been auto-adjusted to match the new start date (January 26, 2025) for manufacturing work. This ensures subsequent MRP and procurement activities utilize the latest schedule info. The project logistics controller can choose to initiate procurement right after saving or when the WBS element is released for execution, offering further date checks during WBS approval.

The 'Monitor Material Coverage' app in SAP Cloud ERP leverages demand data generated by projects to deliver actionable insights into overall material status and potential shortages.

Image: “Monitor Material Coverage” App lists material demands from projects and analysis supply, available stock and upcoming shortage periods.

If materials must be procured directly from a supplier, the corresponding purchase requisitions and purchase orders are created using the material demand dates from the project schedule and the Project Demand app.

Image: “Monitor Material Coverage” App provides link to purchase order  generated from project demand app

How does integrated project procurement help project manufacturers ? 

This close integration between project timeline planning and company logistics processes enhances project planning quality, enabling project controllers to:

  • Eliminate manual rework and email chains: Requirement dates flow from project WBS activities directly to procurement, updating all linked materials' delivery dates with one change.
  • Reduce risks of stockouts and site delays: Ensures materials are available when manufacturing and assembly begin as planned, minimizing last-minute expedites.
  • Optimize working capital and space: Prevents early deliveries that tie up cash and overcrowd staging areas.
  • Improves supplier collaboration:  Early reschedule notifications allow smoother renegotiations, better adherence to framework agreements, and fewer change-order disputes.
  • Aligns logistics and financials with project reality:  Commitments, Goods Receipt, Work-In-Progress capitalization and revenue recognition stay synchronized with actual progress, improving forecast accuracy and month-end close.

Such automatic synchronization between project timelines and downstream logistics processes can be easily achieved by companies that use SAP Cloud ERP in combination with SAP Project and Resource Management, as the two modules are natively integrated.

By managing customer projects end-to-end, linking timelines to WBS and material requirements, driving MRP scheduling, and coordinating procurement processes, companies can achieve the full range of benefits discussed: timely material arrival, fewer site delays, reduced manual logistics and finance coordination, and more predictable cost and cash-flow outcomes.

If this blog sparked your interest, visit www.sap.com/prm or www.sap.com/erp to dive deeper. You’ll find detailed product information, guided product tours to see SAP Project and Resource Management and SAP Cloud ERP in action, and trial offerings so you can experience the value firsthand. Take the next step and explore what SAP can do for your projects.

entry.title: 🇨🇭 Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core (Risch-Rotkreuz, Switzerland)
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core and Python. You do not need to have any background in the topic, but a lot of curiosity!

In this CodeJam you will learn how to use Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core to implement a retrieval augmented generation (RAG) use case to improve the responses of large language models (LLMs) and reduce hallucinations. You will learn how to deploy an LLM and the orchestration service on SAP AI Core and query it via SAP AI Launchpad and the Python SDK. Furthermore, you will learn about the most important genAI concepts and create and use embeddings to improve your RAG response and build your own chatbot with memory.

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have, to have the instructions on a separate screen.

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, March 16, 2026 from 09:30 - 15:00 local time in Risch-Rotkeuz, Switzerland (CET). The language of the event and the content will be English.

Event Address: GAMBIT Consulting AG, Suurstoffi 22, 6343 Risch-Rotkreuz, Switzerland (8th floor)

  • The event is kindly being hosted by GAMBIT – THANK YOU!
  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocates @ajmaradiaga and @Dan_Wroblewski.

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 22 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About 2 weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance and will receive further instructions.

entry.title: New Content Updates for Product Compliance
entry.content:
With the latest Product Compliance release, many new compliance requirement versions have been added to the embedded regulatory content. Among these is the TRGS Occupational Exposure Limits for Germany. To accommodate the additional data included in this compliance requirement version, we have expanded the Manage Compliance Requirement – SDS app.

Embedded regulatory content, by the numbers:

  • 15 Compliance requirements for dangerous goods management
  • 92 Compliance requirements for occupational exposure limits
  • 102 Compliance requirements for safety data sheet management
  • 142 Compliance requirements for safety data sheet authoring
  • 273 Compliance requirements for product marketability
  • 858 Embedded regulatory graphics
  • Over 31,000 Embedded regulatory phrases
  • Over 370,000 Embedded listed substances and other listed substance content

To see which compliance requirement versions are available, check out the SAP Help Portal pages for:

  • Dangerous Goods Content
  • Product Marketability Content
  • Safety Data Sheet Management Content
  • Safety Data Sheet Authoring Content
  • Occupational Exposure Limits Content  

There are also two new read APIs for phrase-enabled fields and compliance requirement versions. These APIs help fill in any gaps in the regulatory content. For example, if you have a phrase imported that only contains the Phrase ID, you can use the read API to retrieve the rest of the information and translations that match the Phrase ID. You can find both APIs on the Business Accelerator Hub here.

A first step toward the vision of allowing users to import and view content which has been brought into the system is here. A new app, Manage Regulatory Content Updates, is available to view information on content imports to your product compliance system from the Regulatory Content Service. This app is currently only available in public cloud systems.

In this demo video you will see setting up a third-party content provider communication arrangement to product compliance for regulatory content as well as a glimpse at the new app. 

You can find the help portal documentation for Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0666 (Product Compliance - Regulatory Content Partner Integration) here.

You can also check on upcoming features in the Roadmap Explorer. For information on all new product compliance features, visit the What's New section of the SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Re: Request for Guidance on SAP TRM Valuation and Update...
entry.content:
1. Key Date Valuation → Define Amortization Procedure
To calculate accruals, amortizations, and deferrals for financial instruments such as bonds, money market instruments, loans, and securities.
How it works
You define amortization methods (e.g., straight-line, effective interest method). SAP uses these rules to calculate: Accrued interest, Premium/discount amortization, Deferred charges/income
Where it is applied
Money Market (MM), Securities (SEC), Loans (LOAN), FX with interest components

2. Define One-Step Price Valuation Procedure
To perform simple mark-to-market valuation using a single market price (e.g., closing price).
How it works
SAP takes the market price and compares it with the book value. The difference is posted as: Unrealized gain, Unrealized loss
Where it is applied
Securities, Listed instruments, Simple valuation scenarios

3. Define Security Valuation Procedure
To perform detailed valuation of securities based on: Market prices, Yield curves, Clean/dirty price, Accrued interest
How it works
You configure: Price type (e.g., clean price, dirty price), Valuation class, Update types for valuation differences
Where it is applied
Bond portfolios, Equity portfolios, Mutual funds, Treasury investment portfolios

4. Define Foreign Currency Valuation Procedure
To revalue foreign currency positions at period-end. if contract currency is different from company code currency
How it works
SAP compares transaction exchange rate vs closing exchange rate. Posts: FX gain/loss, FX valuation differences
Where it is applied
FX forwards, FX swaps, FX spot deals, Any instrument with foreign currency exposure

5. Define Rate Valuation Procedure for Forward Exchange Transactions
To value forward points and forward premiums/discounts.
How it works
SAP uses forward curves or interest rate differentials. Calculates: Forward revaluation, NPV of forward legs
Where it is applied
FX forwards, FX swaps NDFs (Non-deliverable forwards)

6. Define Index Valuation Procedure
To value instruments linked to: Inflation index, Commodity index, Interest rate index (e.g., LIBOR, SOFR)
How it works
SAP reads index values from market data. Recalculates cash flows based on index movement.
Where it is applied
Inflation-linked bonds, Commodity-linked notes, Floating-rate instruments

7. Determine Impairment Procedure
To comply with accounting standards (IFRS 9, GAAP) for credit impairment.
How it works
SAP checks if the instrument is impaired. Posts: Impairment loss, Reversal of impairment
Where it is applied
Securities, Loans, Money market placements

8. Define Current Portion Transfer Procedure
To transfer long-term positions into short-term as they approach maturity.
How it works
SAP identifies remaining maturity. Transfers balances from long-term GL to short-term GL.
Where it is applied
Long-term loans, Long-term investments, Bonds

Define Position Management Procedure
Is combination of above 8 procedure for investment or Debt. Based on nature which is applicable.

Key Date Valuation
Valuation on a given date e.g month end in most of cases. As there are part of month end closing.

Derived Business Transactions
How the values are derived from main contract to these procedure.

entry.title: Re: Error in MIGO after the closing of a production order
entry.content: Thanks for pointing this out. You’re right; according to SAP Help and BS13/TJ07, goods movements are not permitted once the order is in CLSD status. My earlier suggestion about SAP removing the restriction was incorrect — I had mixed up the flexibility allowed at TECO with the hard block at CLSD. If the requirement is to block receipts earlier (like at TECO), then user status profiles (via BS02/OPJH) or a BAdI implementation are still valid approaches. That way, you can replicate ECC-like stricter blocking before CLSD. For CLSD itself, the system already enforces the block standardly.

Custom CDS Views - Using Multiple Data Sources

You should be able to create multiple CDS views and then combine their results in a consuming application or report.

1. Define individual CDS views for each dataset you want to combine.

2. Use these CDS views in a custom analytical query or report where you can aggregate the results.

3. If necessary, you can export the data from these views and perform ‘UNION ALL’ operations in external tools like SAP Analytics Cloud.

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Re: How to disable unnecessary or inactive super administ...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

If you need to change the current Super Users to normal user or normal admin, then you need to work with Super User account and delete any unnecessary authorizations from the users.

The detailed steps are documented in KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/1511008.

Once those S-users have less authorizations than your super user account, they will not be listed as super user and will disappear from the super user list.

Hope this helps.

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Simplify Your Test Setup: Introducing the Test Starter Concept for Your UI5 Projects
entry.content:
With UI5 version 1.124 (Note: A downport for UI5 1.120 is available with 1.120.24) the test starter concept is officially enabled for UI5 application projects. Previously, this concept was mainly used in UI5 framework libraries. This guide explains how to migrate an application project’s test setup to a test starter-based setup. 

In the previous setup, the central entry point for running tests is webapp/test/testsuite.qunit.html, which usually references testsuite.qunit.js located next to it. Test runners like UI5 Test Runner or WebdriverIO QUnit Service also request both files. 

webapp/test/testsuite.qunit.html

To migrate to the new setup, replace the two script tags with one new script tag. This tag loads the sap/ui/test/starter/createSuite module, references the testsuite.qunit.js file, and configures the test namespace. This module creates the actual test suite based on the configuration in the testsuite.qunit.js file. 

Old

<!doctype html> 
<html> 
    <head> 
        <title>QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: ui5.myapp</title> 
        <script src="../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-redirect.js"></script> 
        <script src="testsuite.qunit.js" data-sap-ui-testsuite></script> 
    </head> 
    <body></body> 
</html>

New

<!doctype html> 
<html> 
    <head> 
        <title>QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: ui5.myapp</title> 
        <!-- Adjust the paths in the following lines to reflect your component namespace --> 
        <script
            src="../resources/sap/ui/test/starter/createSuite.js"   
            data-sap-ui-testsuite="test-resources/ui5/myapp/testsuite.qunit"
            data-sap-ui-resource-roots='{ 
                "test-resources.ui5.myapp": "./" 
            }' 
        ></script> 
    </head> 
    <body></body> 
</html>

 

webapp/test/testsuite.qunit.js

In the previous setup, the testsuite.qunit.js file registered the relevant test pages. This remains true in the new setup, but the number of configuration options has increased significantly, and the file structure has changed. In the new setup, testsuite.qunit.js must return an object representing the test suite configuration. We describe the available configuration options in detail in UI5 Test Starter – Configuration Options. Unlike the previous setup, the configuration doesn’t reference HTML-based test pages. Instead, it points to test pages written in JavaScript or TypeScript. 

Old

window.suite = function () { 
    var suite = new parent.jsUnitTestSuite(); 
    var aParts = location.pathname.match(/(.*\/)(?:[^/]+)/); 
    var sContextPath = aParts && aParts[1]; 
    suite.addTestPage(sContextPath + "unit/unitTests.qunit.html"); 
    suite.addTestPage(sContextPath + "integration/opaTests.qunit.html"); 
    return suite; 
};

New

sap.ui.define(function () { 
    "use strict"; 

    return {
        name: "QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: ui5.myapp", 
        defaults: { 
            // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
            page: "ui5://test-resources/ui5/myapp/Test.qunit.html?testsuite={suite}&test={name}", 
            qunit: { 
                version: 2 
            }, 
            sinon: { 
                version: 1 
            }, 
            ui5: { 
                language: "EN", 
                theme: "sap_horizon" 
            }, 
            coverage: {
                // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                only: "ui5/myapp/", 
                // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                never: "test-resources/ui5/myapp/" 
            }, 
            loader: { 
                paths: { 
                    // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                    "ui5/myapp": "../" 
                } 
            } 
        }, 
        tests: { 
            "unit/unitTests": { 
                title: "Unit tests for ui5.myapp" 
            }, 
            "integration/opaTests": { 
                title: "Integration tests for ui5.myapp" 
            } 
        } 
    }; 
});

 

webapp/test/unit/unitTests.qunit.js

Previously, the test pages unitTests.qunit.js and opaTests.qunit.js registered a function to be executed after UI5 booted, loaded all test files (Qunit or OPA5) ,and started the test execution. The new Test starter concept simplifies these files significantly. Their only task is to require all relevant test pages. 

Old

QUnit.config.autostart = false; 

sap.ui.getCore().attachInit(function () { 

    "use strict"; 

    sap.ui.require(["unit/controller/Main.qunit"], function () { 
        QUnit.start(); 
    }); 
});

New

sap.ui.define(["./controller/Main.qunit"]);

 

webapp/test/integration/opaTests.qunit.js

Old

QUnit.config.autostart = false; 

sap.ui.getCore().attachInit(function () { 

    "use strict";

    sap.ui.require(["integration/HelloJourney"], function () { 
        QUnit.start(); 
    });

});

New

sap.ui.define(["./HelloJourney"]);

 

webapp/test/unit/unitTests.qunit.html and webapp/test/integration/opaTests.qunit.html

You can now delete webapp/test/unit/unitTests.qunit.html and webapp/test/integration/opaTests.qunit.html, as they are no longer needed.

 

webapp/test/Test.qunit.html

Instead, create a new generic test execution page called webapp/test/Test.qunit.html. This file executes the test pages migrated in the previous step.

<!doctype html> 
<html> 
    <head>
        <meta charset="utf-8" />
        <!-- Adjust the paths in the following lines to reflect your component namespace --> 
        <script
            src="../resources/sap/ui/test/starter/runTest.js" 
            data-sap-ui-resource-roots='{ 
                "test-resources.ui5.myapp": "./" 
            }'
        ></script> 
</head> 
<body class="sapUiBody"> 
    <div id="qunit"></div> 
    <div id="qunit-fixture"></div> 
</body>
</html>

 

TypeScript

Note: The following section is only relevant, if your project is using TypeScript.

With UI5 1.142, TypeScript support for defining a test suite has improved. Simply import the sap/ui/test/starter/config/SuiteConfiguration types offered by UI5.  

import type {SuiteConfiguration} from "sap/ui/test/starter/config"; 

export default { 
    name: "QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: ui5.myapp", 
    defaults: { 
            // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
            page: "ui5://test-resources/ui5/myapp/Test.qunit.html?testsuite={suite}&test={name}", 
            qunit: { 
                version: 2 
            }, 
            sinon: { 
                version: 1 
            }, 
            ui5: { 
                language: "EN", 
                theme: "sap_horizon" 
            }, 
            coverage: {
                // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                only: "ui5/myapp/",
                // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                never: "test-resources/ui5/myapp/" 
            }, 
            loader: { 
                paths: {
                    // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                    "ui5/myapp": "../" 
                } 
            } 
        }, 
        tests: { 
            "unit/unitTests": { 
                title: "Unit tests for ui5.myapp" 
            }, 
            "integration/opaTests": { 
                title: "Integration tests for ui5.myapp" 
            } 
        }
} satisfies SuiteConfiguration;

 

Dive Deeper 

The UI5 Demo Kit provides detailed documentation on the general concept and various configuration options, helping you get the most out of the test starter for your project. For a more interactive learning experience, watch the UI5ers live #43 session, where we presented the test starter concept. 

 

Summary

The new test starter concept simplifies the test setup, reduces the boilerplate code needed to write a QUnit test, and ensures the loading of commonly used testing frameworks (such as QUnit, Sinon.JS, and qunit-reporter). It ensures these testing frameworks and your test modules load asynchronously and comply with the Content Security Policy. It also allows moving the configuration of the testing frameworks out of the test code. We look forward to your feedback and experiences when applying the test starter concept to your UI5 projects.

entry.title: The Only Script you would ever need for Message Logging and Custom Headers in SAP CI
entry.content:
Introduction

If you are familiar with a previous blog I had written on Configurable Custom headers in SAP CI where you could just add more custom headers in SAP CI message just by configuring the iflow and without having to edit the iflow and then transport it you understand how important and useful this solution is.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-ci-user-defined-search-made-easy-and-automated/ba-p/13564262

This solution was however limited in the sense that it didn't allow you to log the payload in the same step, didn't work at all if the value to be logged in custom headers had to be derived from an expression, or if the value to be logged was actually a file path for instance and shouldn't be evaluated as an xpath, or the value was just a constant or if the value was the be derived from a gpath.

This advanced solution enables 360 degree message logging and Custom header logging for all these scenarios.

Solution 

This upgraded Script handles all such cases as we shortly see.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import javax.xml.xpath.XPathFactory;
import javax.xml.xpath.XPathExpression;
import javax.xml.xpath.XPathConstants;
import javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper



def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    def propertyMap = message.getProperties()
     def headers = message.getHeaders();
     def value = headers.get("SAPJMSRetries");
   int SAPJMSRetries = -1;
    if(value != null)
    {
    
      SAPJMSRetries =   Integer.parseInt((String)value);
    }      
    //Read logger from the Message Properties
    String logger = propertyMap.get("logger");
    String logPayloadFileName = propertyMap.get("logPayloadFileName");
    
    
    if(logger != null && logger.equals("1") && SAPJMSRetries == -1){//log payload only once
        if(messageLog != null){
           // messageLog.setStringProperty("Logging#1", "Printing Payload As Attachment")
            if(logPayloadFileName == null)
                logPayloadFileName = "payload";
            messageLog.addAttachmentAsString(logPayloadFileName, body, "text/plain");
         }
    }
    message = logKeys(message);
  return message;
}

def Message logKeys(Message message) 
{
    
def xml = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;

    
    def properties = message.getProperties();
    
    def search_attributes = properties.get("search_attributes");
    def attribute_xpaths = properties.get("attribute_xpaths");
    def json = null;

    if( (search_attributes != null && attribute_xpaths != null) && (!search_attributes.equals("") && !attribute_xpaths.equals("")) )
    {
        def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    
         String[] search_attributes_array = search_attributes.split("#");
         String[] attribute_xpaths_array = attribute_xpaths.split("#");
     


        if(search_attributes_array.length == attribute_xpaths_array.length )
        {
            String saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment = ""; //this is needed if the xpath occurs multiple Runtime
            //as SAP CI monitoring truncates the values if they are too long - in display defeating the purpose
            //of the headers
            
          
        
  
            for(int i=0; i<attribute_xpaths_array.length; i++)
            {
             String temp_value= "";
            
                //check if the attributeXpaths field contains a xpath or a constant value 
                if(( attribute_xpaths_array[i].startsWith("XPATH:") )  ) //if you want to enter a value like /folder1/folder2 enter it just dont add XPATH: in beginning and it would be treated like a constant
                {
                    def xpath_exp = attribute_xpaths_array[i].substring(6,attribute_xpaths_array[i].length());
                    try{
                          def xpath = XPathFactory.newInstance().newXPath()
                          def builder     = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance().newDocumentBuilder()
                          def inputStream = new ByteArrayInputStream( xml.bytes )
                          def records     = builder.parse(inputStream).documentElement
                        XPathExpression expr = xpath.compile(xpath_exp)
                        def nodes = expr.evaluate(  records, XPathConstants.NODESET );
            
                        if(nodes != null)
                        {
                            for(int j = 0; j < nodes.getLength(); j++)
                            {
                                //messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty(search_attributes_array[i], nodes.item(j).getTextContent());
                                temp_value = temp_value+nodes.item(j).getTextContent()+",";
                            }
                            if((temp_value.length() > 1) && temp_value.endsWith(","))
                                temp_value = temp_value.substring(0,temp_value.length()-1);
                        }
                    }
                    catch(Exception e)//what if its a invalid xpath and the person just really has a / in the value then add it as is
                    {
                          temp_value =   attribute_xpaths_array[i];//un adulterated value aded to custom header 
                    }
                }
                else if(attribute_xpaths_array[i].startsWith("GPATH:"))
                {
                    try{
                    if(json == null)
                        json = new JsonSlurper().parseText(xml)//ignore the variable name its json
                        
                     def gpath = attribute_xpaths_array[i].substring(6,attribute_xpaths_array[i].length());
                     
                    temp_value =   (Eval.me('json', json, "json.${gpath}")).toString();
                    
                    }
                    catch(Exception e)
                    {
                        //nothing to be done here. If this fails this shouldn't impact message processing in any way by design.
                         messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("Exception Encountered in Logging", e.message, "text/plain");
                    }
                }
                else//it doesnt contain any / hence it is not a xpath which tells us not to treat it as an xpath and might just be an Expression
                {
                  temp_value =   attribute_xpaths_array[i];//un adulterated value aded to custom header 
                }
                if(temp_value != null)
                {
                    //temp_value = temp_value;
                    messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty(search_attributes_array[i], temp_value);
                    saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment = saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment + search_attributes_array[i] + " : " +temp_value+"\n";
                }

            }
            if(saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment != null && !saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment.equals("") && saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment.length() > 200)
                 messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("FullTextOfTruncatedCustomHeaders", saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment, "text/plain");
               
        }
    }

        return message;
}

 

Let's consider following XML sample as inbound XML payload

<Invoice>
  <InvHeader>
    <InvNumber>4385689</InvNumber>
    <CustName>Cust 1</CustName>
  </InvHeader>
  <InvLineItem>
    <Item>
      <ItemNum>100</ItemNum>
    </Item>
    <Item>
      <ItemNum>101</ItemNum>
    </Item>
    <Item>
      <ItemNum>102</ItemNum>
    </Item>
    <Item>
      <ItemNum>103</ItemNum>
    </Item>
  </InvLineItem>
</Invoice>

 

Iflow- 

You just need a content modifier with the logger parameters and the actual script after it.

Parameter / Properties format - 

logPayloadFileName - Give the file Name for the log attachment for saving the message as an attachment

logger - 1 : message will be logged as an attachment , 0 : Message wont be logged

search_attributes : Names of the search attributes / Custom headers separated by #

example : HTTPStatus#InvNumber#CustName#ItemNumbers

attribute_xpaths : Values of the custom headers specified above in same order separated by #, Keep data type as java.lang.String

example :

${header.CamelHttpResponseCode}#XPATH://InvNumber#XPATH://CustName#XPATH://InvLineItem/Item/ItemNum

 

 

As you can see from the message log the Custom headers were created from the supplied expression, and XPATH's, if there were multiple xpath matches all those values were concatenated, separated by ",". If you only want only the first xpath matche value do specify [0] explicitly.

 

 A salient feature is that the allowed character limit for a header is 100 characters, In case this limit is exceeded the script will create an attachment as well for that particular header as the SAP CI custom header would display only 100 characters.

And here is the MPL attachment saved with your custom name

 

Let's have a look at a JSON Payload as an input example

{
	"Invoice": {
		"InvHeader": {
			"InvNumber": 4385689,
			"CustName": "Cust 1"
		},
		"InvLineItem": {
			"Item": [
				{
					"ItemNum": 100
				},
				{
					"ItemNum": 101
				},
				{
					"ItemNum": 102
				},
				{
					"ItemNum": 103
				}
			]
		}
	}
}

search_attributes : 

HTTPStatus#InvNumber#CustName#ItemNumbers#ArchiveFilePath

attribute_xpaths

${header.CamelHttpResponseCode}#GPATH:Invoice.InvHeader.InvNumber#GPATH:Invoice.InvHeader.CustName#GPATH:Invoice.InvLineItem.Item*.ItemNum#/Folder1/Folder2/File1.txt

This should now add the custom headers in exactly same way as it added for the previous XML input and should also add the file path which starts with : so as to tell the script to not evaluate it as a XPATH, and should also add the expression. The GPATHS should start with "GPATH:"



Result:

 

One more important feature is that it checks SAPJMSRetries header and if this is used in a JMS flow this will only add MPL attachment 1 time. 

So use it in your iflows and do add the blog link in your script for helping operations team understand how this works.

don't forget to make the search_attributes and attributes_xpaths externalized parameters, that way you would never have to change the artifact and transport it if you need additional custom headers ever.

entry.title: Re: Creating a Hybrid CAP (Node.js) Profile with PostgreSQL on BTP from Business Application Studio
entry.content:
Hi @arunkrishnamoorthy1988, 

Thank you for pointing out this issue. After relaunching the application, I observed the same problem.

The issue was caused by PostgreSQL requiring an SSL-encrypted connection while CAP/Node was unable to validate the server certificate, which resulted in a TLS handshake failure and a connection timeout.

The solution consists of providing the correct certificate so that rejectUnauthorized: true can be used, ensuring both encryption and proper certificate validation.

"ssl": {
  "rejectUnauthorized": true,  
  "ca": "<same_as_sslcert>"
},

I have updated the blog accordingly. Thank you for your feedback !

entry.title: Re: calculate with boolean
entry.content:
Don't confuse ABAP_BOOL type to store the characters 'X' (true) or space (false) with the boolean algebra.

The boolean algebra can be done with ABAP bit operators (example proposed) on variables of type X or XSTRING.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Source to Contract 2601 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Source to Contract Community, and welcome to our 2602 Key Innovations blog.
In this post, we’re sharing the main updates included in the Q1 2026 release for SAP Ariba source-to-contract solutions.

Here’s a closer look at what’s new this quarter.



SAP Ariba Contract Management

Generating Contract Summaries in SAP Ariba Contracts Using AI (SCONTR-1266)

When buyers or suppliers open a contract workspace, SAP Ariba Contracts now automatically generates a contract summary. The summary is based on the contract header information and is created using SAP AI Core services.

This applies to both new and existing contracts. If contract details change during the lifecycle, users can generate a new version of the summary. If the generated summary is not satisfactory, users can retry, within a predefined limit. The retry limit can be adjusted through configuration of the SAP AI Core instance, if needed.

This change helps users get a quick overview of a contract without reviewing the full document immediately.

 

Excluding Ad Hoc Tasks During Baseline-to-Supplier Contract Data Transfer (SCONTR-1556)

During pre-award negotiations, supplier contracts are often created by copying data from a baseline contract. With this release, buyers can configure the system to exclude ad hoc tasks during this data transfer.

Ad hoc tasks are typically not inherited from templates and are often informal or exploratory in nature. If copied into supplier contracts, they can unintentionally become binding steps. Excluding these tasks helps ensure that supplier contracts include only the required contractual information.

 

SAP Ariba Guided Sourcing

Enhancements to Manual Award Scenarios (SOURCE-2594)

Manual award scenarios in guided sourcing have been updated to improve usability when allocating items or lots to multiple suppliers.

Users can now open an "Allocate Award" popup from the award allocation panel. This popup allows users to:

  • Allocate awards by percentage or quantity

  • Enter allocation values for each supplier

  • View the total allocated value

  • Apply or save allocations in a single place

These changes reduce the need to scroll through long lists when working with multiple suppliers.

 

Modifying Event Duration and Searching Sourcing Requests Using Joule (SOURCE-2534)

Joule can now be used to adjust the duration of open RFP and RFI events. If an event includes a task, the approver must still approve the timing change for it to take effect. Auction event durations cannot be modified using Joule.

Joule can also be used to view sourcing requests created within a specific timeframe and to open a specific sourcing request directly.

 

Creating Optimization Scenarios Based on Score (SOURCE-2690)

For guided sourcing events where scoring is enabled, buyers can now create optimization scenarios with the objective of maximizing score.

A new "Maximize Score" option has been added to the "Create Scenario" page. This allows award scenarios to be based on overall scoring results, rather than other criteria alone.

The Q1 2026 release introduces targeted updates across contract management and guided sourcing. Each change is designed to reduce unnecessary steps and make existing workflows easier to manage.

These features can be adopted independently, depending on your current setup and processes.

Stay tuned for our additional upcoming blog posts and follow me to stay informed on upcoming feature releases across SAP Ariba. Once, these items are officially released on February 14th, the feature reference IDs (i.e. SC-22524) can help to find more detailed information on http://help.sap.com.

Thank you for being a part of the SAP Ariba community and we look forward to continuing our journey of innovation together!

Resources:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement and Network
  • What’s New
